block.p: FORT WASHINGTON 'Little Red'In Words and Music

The children's book ''The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge'' is based on a true story, and its real-life inspiration will be celebrated on Saturday. A reading of the book, written by Hildegarde H. Swift, will culminate the Little Red Lighthouse Festival in Fort Washington Park. ''Little Red'' was erected in Sandy Hook, N.J., in 1880, and was moved to its present location in 1921. When the lighthouse escaped destruction in 1951, it became property of the Parks Department, which is a host of the festival.

Events will include tours of the lighthouse, hay rides, craft activities for children and exhibits by nautical and conservationist organizations. There will also be musical performances by the Latin Jazz Alliance, Freddie Hartington's Steel Drum Band and Jerry Joy Music Alliance. Fire Department boats will spray rainbows of water into the air above swimmers participating in the Little Red Lighthouse swim.

FULTON FERRY 'Nouveau Swing' On the East River

Starting today, the ''Celebrate Brooklyn! Pier Dance Party'' will extend over three consecutive Sundays at the Fulton Ferry Landing Pier. Tonight, opening night, features Joe Battaglia and his 18-piece New York Big Band playing ''nouveau swing'' from the 1940's to today.
Next Sunday, Los Jovenes Del Barrio, a charanga band, will play, and on Sept. 24, Ingrid Lucia and the Flying Neutrinos (shown below), will play New Orleans jazz, swing and blues.

The series is being put on by the Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corporation, which was created in 1998 to work in conjunction with the planned 70-acre park that will cover 1.3 miles along the East River from Atlantic Avenue to the Manhattan Bridge. Food and drinks will be on sale at the River Cafe.
Celebrate Brooklyn! Pier Dance Party; today, , next Sunday and Sept. 24, from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m.; Fulton Ferry Landing Pier; free, but tickets are required: (718) 855-7882, extension 46.
BROOKLYN HEIGHTS Curious Things, mNatural and Artificial

A collection of the ''rare, strange and marvelous'' on view at the Rotunda Gallery is titled ''Wunderkammer: Wonderworks,'' based on the 17th-century tradition of the Wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosity. Precursors to the modern museum, wunderkammers combined biological oddities, zoological rarities and geological specimens in displays with works of art.
At the Rotunda, works include collections of globes, voodoo hats and earrings, collected by Annie Herron, who is shown below, and a trove of Stevie Nicks memorabilia.

''Wunderkammer: Wonderworks,'' through Oct. 21; daily hours Tuesday through Friday, noon to 5 p.m., Saturday 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; the Rotunda Gallery, 33 Clinton Street, near Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn Heights; free; (718) 875-4047.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

WHERE PLAY'S THE THING -- Bookmark-making workshops and Portia's Playhouse -- a theater where costumes, props, lights and sounds set a stage for young imaginations -- are part of the Staten Island Children's Museum workshops Saturday and next Sunday, noon to 5 p.m.; 1000 Richmond Terrace, near Snug Harbor Road; $2 plus museum admission: $4; children under 2 and museum members free; (718) 273-2060.

BIKE HELMETS FOR CRIME STOPPERS -- The Safety First Crime Prevention Fair, sponsored by the 103rd Precinct Community Council, brings the police and residents together in eastern Queens to work on crime prevention; bicycle helmets will be given to children who participate in a bicycle antitheft and safety program; Saturday 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.; 195th Place between Hillside and 90th Avenues, Hollis; free; (718) 657-8195.

STARRING IN HIS OWN TRIBUTE -- Dave Valentin, the jazz flutist from the Bronx, stars in a tribute to himself in Hunts Point; Friday 8 p.m.; the Live from the Edge Theater, 940 Garrison Avenue, (entrance on Manida Street) the Bronx; $10; (718) 542-4139.
